title: City News update: Tata Steel, Stagecoach, WPP, HSS
text:
City News update: Tata Steel, Stagecoach, WPP, HSS City News update: Tata Steel, Stagecoach, WPP, HSS THE latest updates from City & Business… PUBLISHED: 12:42, Thu, Aug 27, 2015 | UPDATED: 12:47, Thu, Aug 27, 2015 GETTY TATA Steel to cut 250 jobs at South Wales plant Tata set to shed steel jobs 
TATA Steel is to cut 250 jobs as it mothballs part of a plant in South Wales. 
The move by Europe’s second biggest steel producer will hit agency workers mainly at Llanwern as Tata concentrates production of hot rolled coil at Port Talbot. 
Tata’s director of Strip Products UK Stuart Wilkie said: “Surging, and often unfairly traded, imports have combined with a strong pound to create a challenging environment. 
"The changes will reduce our costs and enable us to focus on generating more value.” Fuel drop hits Stagecoach 
FALLING fuel costs are hitting demand for Stagecoach’s inter-city coach services in North America as more people take to their cars. 
The FTSE 250 transport group said like-for-like revenue at megabus.com North America in the three months to July 31 was down 3.4 per cent on last year. 
But Stagecoach said it was on track to meet forecasts after a strong performance by its UK rail division, where revenue increased by 5.5 per cent over the period. 
Its shares fell 9¼p to 365p. Bullish on China woe 
WPP boss Sir Martin Sorrell says he remains a “raging bull” on China despite a stock market meltdown and declining sales growth there for the world’s biggest advertising group. 
A strong performance in North America, where second-quarter sales rose 3.5 per cent, compared with 0.7 per cent growth in emerging markets as WPP grew half-year headline pre-tax profi t by 12.1 per cent to £596million. 
Sorrell said: “There are worries about the slowing of growth but that was inevitable .” 
He added 2015 will be another tough year, but expects a lift from next year’s Rio Olympics, the Euro 2016 football and US presidential election. HSS profit warning 
ABOUT £80million was wiped from the value of tool hire company HSS yesterday as it sounded another profit warning to continue its dismal performance since its stock market listing last February at 210p a share. 
HSS shares crashed 50p to 79p after news that its half-year pre-tax loss had widened to £14.1milion from £11.3million, in line with guidance issued in June when it blamed lower customer activity in the run up to the general election and less demand for cooling equipment. 
Chief executive Chris Davies said conditions had deteriorated in August and “now expects full-year earnings to be below market expectations”. Related articles
